questions.text: What is the central goal of Functional Imaging II?
questions.explanation: The lecture repeatedly asks "How to make metabolic processes visible?" emphasizing functional and biochemical imaging.

questions.text: Which principle allows metabolic processes to be visualized in nuclear medicine?
questions.explanation: Slides reference George de Hevesy and the tracer principle as the basis for visualizing metabolism.

questions.text: What is the role of the carrier molecule in a radiopharmaceutical?
questions.explanation: The slide "Radiopharmaceutical" shows that the carrier molecule determines which tissue the tracer accumulates in.

questions.text: Why do different radiopharmaceuticals accumulate in different organs?
questions.explanation: The slide explicitly states: "Different radiopharmaceuticals accumulate in different parts of the body, depending on functional aspects of tissue."

questions.text: What causes both physiological and pathological uptake in PET images?
questions.explanation: The slide "What can we see in a nuclear image?" highlights both physiological and pathological uptake.

questions.text: Why is imaging time point critical in nuclear medicine?

options.B: Because tracer kinetics vary over time

questions.explanation: Slides show that each radiopharmaceutical has its own kinetics, leading to different images at different times.

questions.text: What additional information can be derived by imaging at multiple time points?
questions.explanation: The slide states: "By acquiring at different time points, the overall pharmacokinetics can be visualized."

questions.text: Which modalities belong to nuclear medicine?
questions.explanation: The slide "Which are the most common nuclear medicine modalities?" lists Scintigraphy, SPECT, and PET.

questions.text: What dimensionality does scintigraphy provide?
questions.explanation: Scintigraphy is explicitly labeled as 2D on the modality slide.

questions.text: How is radiation most commonly detected in nuclear medicine?

options.B: Indirect detection using scintillators and PMTs

questions.explanation: The detection slide shows indirect detection using scintillators coupled to photomultiplier tubes.

questions.text: What is the function of a scintillator in nuclear imaging?

options.B: Convert gamma photons into visible light

questions.explanation: Slides show gamma photons converted to light before amplification in PMTs.

questions.text: What advantage do semiconductor detectors offer?

options.B: Direct conversion of radiation to electrical signal

questions.explanation: The slide "Direct detection" shows semiconductors directly converting radiation to charge.

questions.text: What replaces optical lenses in scintigraphy and SPECT?
questions.explanation: The slide "What do we use as lenses?" explicitly answers: collimation.

questions.text: What is the primary function of a parallel-hole collimator?

options.B: Select photons traveling in specific directions

questions.explanation: The diagram shows only photons traveling approximately parallel reaching the detector.

questions.text: How does a pinhole collimator differ from a parallel-hole collimator?
questions.explanation: The pinhole diagram shows image magnification depending on source distance.

questions.text: What trade-off is fundamental in collimation?
questions.explanation: Collimation improves resolution at the cost of sensitivity, as implied across collimator slides.

questions.text: Why is energy windowing used in nuclear imaging?
questions.explanation: The take-home message links energy resolution with scattering suppression.

questions.text: What does SPECT add compared to scintigraphy?
questions.explanation: SPECT is defined as single-photon emission computed tomography (3D).

questions.text: Why must more than 180° be covered in SPECT acquisition?
questions.explanation: The slide lists ">180° covered" as a requirement for tomographic reconstruction.

questions.text: What does the system matrix H describe in SPECT modeling?

options.B: Influence of voxel activity on detector measurements

questions.explanation: Slides define H as the influence of voxel j on detector i at position k.

questions.text: What is the main assumption enabling linear reconstruction models?
questions.explanation: Slides explicitly list "Linearization" as a reconstruction assumption.

questions.text: What does MLEM stand for?
questions.explanation: The slide explicitly defines MLEM as Maximum Likelihood Expectation Maximization.

questions.text: Which steps define iterative reconstruction in MLEM?
questions.explanation: The MLEM slide lists exactly these three steps.

questions.text: Why are iterative methods preferred in nuclear imaging?

options.B: They model system physics and noise

questions.explanation: Iterative reconstruction allows modeling of physics, noise, and system response.

questions.text: What key difference exists between PET and SPECT detection?
questions.explanation: PET modeling slides describe detection of coincident photon pairs.

questions.text: Why does PET not require physical collimators?

options.B: Coincidence detection defines line of response

questions.explanation: Coincidence detection provides electronic collimation in PET.

questions.text: What quantity is reconstructed in PET and SPECT?
questions.explanation: Both PET and SPECT reconstruct spatial tracer activity in Bq.

questions.text: Why is PET typically more sensitive than SPECT?
questions.explanation: PET uses electronic collimation, avoiding the sensitivity loss of physical collimators.

questions.text: What limits spatial resolution in nuclear medicine imaging?
questions.explanation: The take-home slide relates resolution to collimation, scattering, and detector properties.

questions.text: Why is nuclear imaging often combined with CT?
questions.explanation: Hybrid imaging combines functional uptake with anatomical reference.

questions.text: What is the primary source of noise in nuclear imaging?
questions.explanation: Emission imaging is dominated by Poisson photon statistics.

questions.text: Why does scattering degrade image quality?
questions.explanation: Scattered photons are detected at incorrect positions, blurring images.

questions.text: What is the relationship between energy resolution and scatter rejection?

options.B: Better energy resolution improves scatter rejection

questions.explanation: Energy windowing relies on sufficient energy resolution to reject scattered photons.

questions.text: Why is emission tomography fundamentally different from CT?

options.B: Emission sources are inside the patient

questions.explanation: In emission tomography, radiation originates inside the body.

questions.text: What is the main take-home message of Functional Imaging II?

options.B: Functional imaging visualizes biochemical processes using tracers and emission physics

questions.explanation: The final slide summarizes functional imaging, tracers, emission tomography, and reconstruction.
